title: Sensory cortex quashes subcortical escape instinct
caption: ğŸ§ ğŸ” New insights in neuroscience reveal how mice can learn to suppress their instinctive escape responses to non-threatening stimuli. This study shows that projections from higher-order visual areas to the ventrolateral geniculate nucleus play a key role in this experience-dependent learning. By repeatedly exposing mice to a looming stimulus without allowing them to escape, researchers found that these animals could learn not to react with fear. This discovery highlights the brain's incredible ability to adapt and modify instinctive behaviors through learning. Such findings offer exciting possibilities for understanding how animals, including humans, can adapt their responses to changing environments. #Neuroscience #BrainPower #Learning #Adaptation #ScienceDiscovery ğŸ­âœ¨

title: Neuroferroptosis in health and diseases
caption:
ğŸ§ âœ¨ Dive into the fascinating world of neuroferroptosis! This type of cell death, driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is making waves in neuroscience. With the brain's high lipid and iron content, understanding neuroferroptosis is crucial as it's linked to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and ALS. Neurons, with their high metabolic demand, rely on lipid antioxidants for protection, while astrocytes offer metabolic support. However, microglial ferroptotic signals can harm astrocytes and neurons, highlighting a complex cellular interplay. This research is reshaping our understanding of brain health and disease, making it a hot topic in neuroscience today. ğŸ”¬ğŸ§¬

#Neuroscience #BrainHealth #Neurodegeneration #Ferroptosis #InnovationInScience

images.author: Munshi MI, Yao SJ, Ben Mamoun C.

images.title: File:Particulates exposure and increased risk of neurodegeneration.jpg
images.author: Ran You, Yuen-Shan Ho, and Raymond Chuen-Chung Chang
images.description:
Airborne PM may enter the brain, inducing neurotoxic effects in the brain and is associated with increased risk of neurodegeneration. Firstly, the airborne PM can enter the brain via either the olfactory route which involves the olfactory system or the trigeminal nerve, or the passing through BBB after enter the circulation. Then the deposited PM can induce neurotoxicity, oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and BBB and NVU damage. These adverse effects in the brain may result in neurodegenerative pathology, such as brain structural abnormality and pathological hallmarks for neurodegenerative diseases. Epidemiological studies has associated PM exposure with cognitive impairment and increased risk of developing neurodegenerative diseases such as AD. (AD Alzheimerâ€™s disease, BBB bloodâ€“brain barrier, NVU neurovascular units, PM Particulate matter.)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8862284/figure/Fig1/

Ran You, Yuen-Shan Ho, and Raymond Chuen-Chung Chang

images.title: File:Examples of Signs and Symptoms of Kidney Ischemia.png
images.author: Jaclorenzo
images.description:
On the left shows the difference in size of the kidneys resulting from Kidney Ischemia. Kidney Ischemia may result in a shrinkage of the kidney to about 2cm or more. On the top right shows the disruption of the mitochondria due to dysfunctions, This leads to release of proapoptotic proteins such as cytochrome c and results in cell death. On the lower right shows inflammation of the glomeruli of the kidneys.
This schematic diagram was drawn using BioRender.com

images.title: File:Major metabolic fluxes in neuron-astrocyte coupling for resting conditions.png
images.author: Prepared by User:OldakQuill from diagram in journal article (see source). Authors of article: Tunahan Cakir, Selma Alsan, Hale Saybasili, Ata Akin, Kutlu Ulgen
images.description:
Major metabolic fluxes (Î¼mol/g tissue/min) in neuron-astrocyte coupling for resting conditions. The fluxes were calculated with the objective of maximizing the glutamate/glutamine/GABA cycle fluxes between the two cell types with subsequent minimization

of Euclidean norm of fluxes, using the uptake rates given in Table 1 as constraints. Thick arrows show uptake and release reactions. Dashed arrows indicate shuttling of metabolites between the two cell types. Only key pathway fluxes are represented here for simplicity. The flux distributions for all the reactions listed in Additional File 1 are given in Additional File 4:Supplementary Table 3. (Description is figure caption from original article)
images.credit: CC-by-2.0 licensed journal article: Cakir, Tunahan; Selma Alsan, Hale Saybasili, Ata Akin, Kutlu Ulgen (2007). "Reconstruction and flux analysis of coupling between metabolic pathways of astrocytes and neurons: application to cerebral hypoxia". Theoretical Biology and Medical Modelling 4 (1): 48. DOI:10.1186/1742-4682-4-48. ISSN 1742-4682. Retrieved on 2007-12-17.

title: The short and long pathways to memory
caption:
ğŸ§ âœ¨ New insights into memory formation! Recent research challenges the traditional view that short-term memory (STM) is necessary for long-term memory (LTM) consolidation. By inhibiting CaMKII, a key kinase in memory processes, scientists found that mice could form LTM without STM in an inhibitory avoidance task. This groundbreaking discovery could reshape our understanding of how memories are formed and stored. Stay curious and keep exploring the wonders of the brain! ğŸ§©ğŸ”

#Neuroscience #Memory #BrainScience #Research #Innovation #ScienceNews

images.description:
Long Short-Term Memory cell, as defined in the original paper of Hochreiter, S. and Schmidhuber, J. (1997) Long Short-Term Memory. Neural computation, 9, 1735-1780.

Notice the lack of the forgetting gate. That did not appear in the 1997 paper.

Slight notational update: "z" is "net" in paper

"cell" is "c" in paper.

title: The brainâ€™s action-mode network
caption: ğŸ§ âœ¨ Dive into the dynamic world of the brain's action-mode network (AMN)! This network, pivotal for goal-directed behavior, heightens arousal, sharpens external focus, and crafts action plans that adapt based on feedback like pain. The AMN is a powerhouse, balancing the brain's default-mode network, which is more about introspection and memory. Think of it as the yin to the default mode's yang. Understanding the AMN's role is crucial as it connects to various physiological functions, influencing everything from task initiation to sympathetic drive. This research highlights the AMN's importance in neuroscience, offering insights into how our brains navigate complex tasks. #Neuroscience #BrainFunction #ActionModeNetwork #MindPower ğŸ’¡ğŸ”

title: Endothelial cells as key players in cerebral small vessel disease
caption:
ğŸ§ âœ¨ New insights into cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) spotlight endothelial cells as crucial players in this vascular disorder, which heightens the risk of stroke and dementia. While lifestyle changes and managing vascular risk factors like hypertension are standard, they often fall short. Emerging evidence reveals that dysfunction in cerebral endothelial cells is a key mechanism in SVD, affecting blood flow, the blood-brain barrier, and interactions within the neuro-glial-vascular unit. This dysfunction can stem from genetic factors or external influences like smoking and diabetes. Promising clinical trials are exploring drugs targeting these endothelial pathways, offering hope for new therapies to slow disease progression and improve outcomes. ğŸŒŸğŸ”¬

#Neuroscience #BrainHealth #StrokeAwareness #EndothelialCells #CerebralSVD #ResearchInnovation
